Award.AbstractNarration:
Polymers composed of molecular segments that can distort when irradiated with light offer a framework for directly converting light into mechanical work. Such materials can be used to engineer new classes of mechanical actuators that are triggered and controlled exclusively with light. One of the more promising light-responsive polymers being studied can generate significant forces upon irradiation with light but is plagued by slow actuation speeds. This award will support fundamental research into the effect of the molecular structure on the photomechanical properties for liquid crystalline copolymers. The insights that emerge can spawn a new class of polymers that could be deployed in systems over a range of length scales where contactless actuation could be enabled such as "soft machines", integrated optomechanical devices, optically-driven microfluidics and microrobots.

This research will test the hypothesis that in azobenzene-functionalized liquid crystal polymers (ALCP), controlling the structure of the flexible spacer in mesogenic azobenzene-functionalized crosslinkers can modulate photomechanical actuation and help realize step-changes in actuation rates, work densities and photomechanical stresses. To study this, acrylate-based crosslinking mesogens with azobenzene-group in the rigid core and flexible spacers of various chain lengths will be synthesized. Using these, a range of liquid crystal polymer films will be created, their photomechanical actuation will be measured and their utility in actuators will be examined. During these studies, the physical underpinnings of inducing/erasing photomechanical strains as a function of intensity and polarization of actinic light will be examined. Ultimately, customized nematic directors will be engineered to enable new actuation modes and set the foundation for novel photomechanical machine elements.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this research was to understand the process-structure-property relationships underpinning the transduction of photonic energy into mechanical work in azobenzene-functionalized liquid crystal polymers. It was hypothesized that controlling the structure of mesogenic azobenzene-functionalized crosslinkers can modulate the photoactuation response in liquid crystal polymers. This hypothesis was examined by undertaking the following research tasks: a) Synthesizing acrylate-based crosslinking mesogens with azobenzene-group in the rigid core and flexible spacers of various aliphatic chain lengths. b) Creating a range of liquid crystal polymer films by crosslinking acrylate-based reactive mesogens with the azobenzene- functionalized monomers. c) Measuring the resulting photomechanical actuation of the polymers and examine their utility in bistable actuators. d) Engineering customized nematic directors to enable new actuation modes and set the foundation for novel photomechanical machine elements.

This research yielded new insights on the effect of the polymer's molecular structure on the direct transduction of light into mechanical work. Using copolymerized systems composed of acrylate-based reactive mesogens and crosslinkers composed of azobenzene in the rigid-core and custom-designed flexible aliphatic chains, step-changes in actuation strains were realized. It was shown that switching of azobenzene using light was transmitted into macroscopic actuation in polymers, when the molecules were not only aligned, but also when they were compactly arranged. The number of the carbon atoms attached to the flexible spacer was key to optimizing these characteristics. This accomplishment was harnessed in a new class of machines composed of actuators and morphing elements, which are all driven exclusively using light. Ultrafast actuators were designed to couple mechanical limit-point instability (snap-through) with photomechanical actuation to generate actuation at millisecond-timescales, even at modest intensities of irradiation. In a demonstrative application, a planar superlattice of these actuators were implemented in a micromirror array that can be actuated with light itself.

Such light driven actuators and structures can spur an entirely new class of photomechanical machines whose adaptivity can be modulated remotely using light, which is either delivered remotely from coherent sources or even harvested from the ambient. These can be envisaged at the micro-meso-millimeter scales where contactless actuation is enabled in soft machines, in integrated optomechanical devices, optically-driven microfluidics, photoactuated microrobots etc. This research involved integral collaborations with the Air Force Research Laboratory and enabled new collaborations between the PI at Pitt and multidisciplinary faculty at Carnegie Mellon, Hope College, Dartmouth, and Stanford. Graduate students and postdocs were trained in a highly interdisciplinary environment involving topics ranging from chemistry, mechanics, polymer physics and robotics.
